																			</div><div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Zhong Li posted Sep 18, 2016 11:03 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_320_513">
																				<img title="Last edited: Sunday, September 18, 2016 11:09 PM EDT" class="d2l-image d2l_1_768_421 d2l-left d2l_1_769_495" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt="Last edited: Sunday, September 18, 2016 11:09 PM EDT">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_319_940"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_868_966" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",83)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Pedestrian Detection with Neural networks">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_869_810" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",84)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Pedestrian Detection with Neural networks">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_321_46">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_870_559" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><span style="margin: 0px;font-size: 12pt;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;"><strong>Task:</strong>
 Pedestrian detection involves automatically identifying pedestrians
apart from other objects in surveillance footage or real-time camera
footage [1]. It is a difficult problem&nbsp;for machines because of
problems such as&nbsp;occlusion&nbsp;and perspective&nbsp;which makes it
 difficult for machines to 'see'.&nbsp;It would be important for
enhancing car-driving safety [2]. Pedestrians are the most vulnerable
and common object on a road so learning to avoid them will be very
important for self-driving cars. It can also be built into the detection
 system of ordinary cars to avoid collision accident with pedestrians.
This technology is also potentially useful for realizing various
functionality in robots. We could imagine that many robots would be
designed to interact with or respond to human in the environment so they
 would need to learn to identify human first. </span></span></p>
<p><span style="margin: 0px;font-size: 12pt;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">Numerous
 methods have been proposed to tackle the problem of pedestrian
detection [3, 4, 5]. In recent years, deep learning based algorithms has
 been applied to the problem and has produced some of the
state-of-the-art results. A group of researchers have proposed a
Switchable Deep Network which automatically learns hierarchical
features, salience maps and representations of body parts to detect
pedestrian [6]. Their model has three major contributions including
enriching a traditional convolutional neural network with a switchable
restricted Boltzmann machine. In 2014, research team at Google developed
 a Deep Neural Network model that can accomplish the task both very
accurately and in real-time (15 frames per second) [7]. They have
advanced the previous state-of-the-art approach using DNN by combining
fast cascade with a cascade of DNN and improved the speed performance of
 the algorithm. It also directly applies the DNN to raw input image
instead of processed features as in other common approaches. </span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><strong><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">Datasets:</span></span></strong></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">1.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">Caltech Pedestrian Dataset</span></span></span></p>
<p><span style="margin: 0px;font-size: 12pt;" lang="EN-US"><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.vision.caltech.edu/Image_Datasets/CaltechPedestrians/"><span style="color: #0563c1;font-family: 等线;font-size: medium;">http://www.vision.caltech.edu/Image_Datasets/CaltechPedestrians/</span></a></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">2.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">Daimler Mono Pedestrian Detection Benchmark Dataset</span></span></span></p>
<p><span style="margin: 0px;font-size: 12pt;" lang="EN-US"><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.gavrila.net/Datasets/Daimler_Pedestrian_Benchmark_D/Daimler_Mono_Ped__Detection_Be/daimler_mono_ped__detection_be.html"><span style="color: #0563c1;font-family: 等线;font-size: medium;">http://www.gavrila.net/Datasets/Daimler_Pedestrian_Benchmark_D/Daimler_Mono_Ped__Detection_Be/daimler_mono_ped__detection_be.html</span></a></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><strong><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">&nbsp;</span></span></strong></span></p>
<p><span style="margin: 0px;font-size: 12pt;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;"><strong>Optimization algorithm:</strong>
 Back propagation will be used to fine tune the model and enable the
classification. This algorithm adjusts the weights of internal nodes of a
 network during learning and improve accuracy of the classification [8].
 It does this by first computing the error between the predicted output
and actual output of each set of input, then use gradient descent to
find the best set of weights which can minimize the error. It
accomplishes it by going down the error surface using optimization
algorithm until it reaches an acceptable error.</span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><strong><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">reference:</span></span></strong></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">1.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">Smedt, F. "Pedestrian Detection For Real-Life Applications". </span><i><span style="font-family: 等线;">Eavise.be</span></i><span style="font-family: 等线;">. N.p., 2016. Web. 19 Sept. 2016.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">2.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">Morphy, Erika. "Advanced Pedestrian Detection Is Here. It Is Very Useful And Makes Me Nervous". </span><i><span style="font-family: 等线;">Computerworld</span></i><span style="font-family: 等线;">. N.p., 2016. Web. 19 Sept. 2016.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">3.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">R.
 Benenson, M. Omran, J. Hosang, and B. Schiele. Ten years of pedestrian
detection, what have we learned? 2nd Workshop on Road scene
understanding and Autonomous driving, ECCV, 2014.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">4.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">M. Oren, C. Papageorgiou, P. Sinha, E. Osuna, and T. Poggio. Pedestrian detection using wavelet templates. CVPR, 1997.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">5.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">K. Rohr. Incremental recognition of pedestrians from image sequences. CVPR, 1993.</span></span></span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">6.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">P. Luo, Y. Tian, X. Wang and X. Tang, "Switchable Deep Network for Pedestrian Detection," </span><em><span style="margin: 0px;font-family: 等线;">2014 IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition</span></em><span style="font-family: 等线;">, Columbus, OH, 2014, pp. 899-906.</span></span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">7.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">A.
 Angelova, A. Krizhevsky, V. Vanhoucke, A. Ogale, D. Ferguson, Real-Time
 Pedestrian Detection With Deep Network Cascades, British Machine Vision
 Conference (BMVC), 2015</span></span></span></p>
<p><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="font-family: 等线;">8.</span><span style="margin: 0px;line-height: normal;font-family: 'Times New Roman';font-style: normal;font-variant: normal;font-weight: normal;font-size-adjust: none;font-stretch: normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></span><span style="margin: 0px;"><span style="margin: 0px;" lang="EN-US"><span style="font-family: 等线;">"Error Backpropagation". </span><i><span style="font-family: 等线;">Willamette.edu</span></i><span style="font-family: 等线;">. N.p., 2016. Web. 19 Sept. 2016.</span></span></span></span></p></div>
																				</div>

																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1446303/View" title="Translating English Text to American Sign Language Using Recurrent Neural Networks">Translating English Text to American Sign Language Using Recurrent Neural Networks</a>
																				</h2>

																			<a href="javascript:void(0);" id="d2l_1_325_297" class="d2l-contextmenu-ph d2l-left" data-contextmenuid="d2l_1_326_638" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" title="Actions for Translating English Text to American Sign Language Using Recurrent Neural Networks" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",85)();return false;'>

																				<span class="d2l-offscreen">Actions for Translating English Text to American Sign Language Using Recurrent Neural Networks</span>
																			</a>
																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_872_395" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">
																				<ul role="presentation" id="d2l_1_326_638" class="d2l-contextmenu">

																			</div><div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Leen Amarin posted Sep 18, 2016 10:55 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_330_989">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_329_340"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_879_725" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",86)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Translating English Text to American Sign Language Using Recurrent Neural Networks">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_880_708" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",87)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Translating English Text to American Sign Language Using Recurrent Neural Networks">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_331_997">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_881_731" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><strong>Project Idea:</strong></p>
<p>Using recurrent neural networks to translate English text to American Sign Language.</p>
<p>Human beings are social animals, dependent on social interactions,
communication through natural language is at the heart of these
interactions. While most people have the ability to communicate through
spoken language, individuals that are deaf or hard of hearing depend on
signed languages. The most widely used sign language in North America is
 American Sign Language. While deaf/hard of hearing individuals can
communicate with hearing individuals through text, it is not ideal, nor
is it optimal, as English is not the primary/first language of signers,
forcing them to communicate in a language that they may not be entirely
comfortable with, leading to miscommunications. Problems with the
English language are actually quite common in signers, as they tend to
have trouble with the grammar, which differs greatly from the conceptual
 language of ASL.</p>
<p>Through artificial intelligence, researchers have been striving to
develop ways to impact how deaf individuals can communicate and learn.
There have been many models and programs developed that strive to
recognize and translate Signed languages to various spoken languages.
With respect to ASL, there have been several systems developed that
strive to translate ASL to English, but research on the opposite is
scarce. Although there has been a program developed to translate text to
 Polish Sign Language, specifically for the use in emergency medical
settings.</p>
<p><strong>Data:</strong></p>
<p>A dataset of American Sign Language signs will be needed for this
project. Depending on the scope of the project, this may either be
limited to the alphabet, and focused mainly on fingerspelling, or it may
 also include common/basic signs. If a wider scope is desired, we may
also need a data set of grammatical facial expressions. We may also need
 a dataset of basic ASL phrases and sentences to train the network to
recognize, understand, and convert English grammar structure, to ASL.</p>
<p><strong>Algorithm:</strong></p>
<p>Based on previous translation models, not necessarily limited to
signed languages, but spoken languages as well. The optimal algorithm to
 be used/explored is a bidirectional recurrent neural network. The
translation will have to take place in a multiple phases, first
converting the grammatical structure to one matching that of ASL, then
translating the corresponding sentence, and finally graphically
producing an avatar to sign the ASL translation.</p>
<p><strong>References:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Sign Language Recognition and Translation: A Multidisciplined Approach from the Field of Artificial Intelligence: <br><a rel="noopener" href="http://jdsde.oxfordjournals.org/content/11/1/94.full.pdf">http://jdsde.oxfordjournals.org/content/11/1/94.full.pdf</a></li>
<li>Speech Translation into Pakistan Sign Language:<br><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.diva-portal.se/smash/get/diva2:832458/FULLTEXT01.pdf">http://www.diva-portal.se/smash/get/diva2:832458/FULLTEXT01.pdf</a></li>
<li>Japanese-to-English Machine Translation Using Recurrent Neural Networks: <a rel="noopener" href="https://cs224d.stanford.edu/reports/GreensteinEric.pdf">https://cs224d.stanford.edu/reports/GreensteinEric.pdf</a></li>
<li>Translating Polish Texts into Sign Language in the TGT System: <a rel="noopener" href="http://thetos.polsl.pl/download/2009%20-%20IADIS-ICAC%20-%20Th022%20-%20TRANSLATING%20POLISH%20TEXTS%20INTO%20SIGN%20LANGUAGE.pdf">http://thetos.polsl.pl/download/2009 - IADIS-ICAC - Th022 - TRANSLATING POLISH TEXTS INTO SIGN LANGUAGE.pdf</a></li>
<li>Using Thetos, Text-into-Sign-Language Translator for Polish: <a rel="noopener" href="http://thetos.polsl.pl/download/2009%20-%20IADIS-ICAC%20-%20Th071-Thetos-Wwa2007-text.pdf">http://thetos.polsl.pl/download/2009%20-%20IADIS-ICAC%20-%20Th071-Thetos-Wwa2007-text.pdf</a></li>

<li>Recognition of Sign Language Using Neural Networks: <a rel="noopener" href="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.88.8019&amp;rep=rep1&amp;type=pdf">http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.88.8019&amp;rep=rep1&amp;type=pdf</a></li>

														<div aria-live="assertive" id="threadListItemContents_1446254" class="d2l-placeholder d2l-placeholder-inner d2l-placeholder-live">
															<div class="d2l-le-disc-post d2l-le-disc-post-border d2l-le-disc-post-unread d2l_1_603_166" data-postid="4518116" data-contextmenuid="postContextMenu_4518116" data-postunreadtextid="postUnread_4518116" data-contentsplaceholderid="threadListItemContents_1446254">
																<div class="d2l-le-disc-posrev">
																	<div>
																		<div class="d2l-hidden">
																			<span class="d2l-fragment"><a style="top: -44px;" name="" tabindex="-1"></a></span>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-inline">
																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1446254/View" title="Malware Detection ANN">Malware Detection ANN</a>
																				</h2>
																			</div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-offscreen">Contains unread posts</div>
																			<a href="javascript:void(0);" id="d2l_1_335_290" class="d2l-contextmenu-ph d2l-left" data-contextmenuid="d2l_1_336_327" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" title="Actions for Malware Detection ANN" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",88)();return false;'>
																				<img src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" class="d2l_1_73_234" alt="">
																				<span class="d2l-offscreen">Actions for Malware Detection ANN</span>
																			</a>
																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_883_582" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">
																				<ul role="presentation" id="d2l_1_336_327" class="d2l-contextmenu">
																					<li role="presentation" id="d2l_1_336_327_MarkAllRead" class="d2l-contextmenu-item">
																						<a role="menuitem" tabindex="-1" class="d2l_1_67_164 vui-dropdown-menu-item-link"><span>Mark All Posts as Read</span></a>
																					</li>
																					<li role="presentation" id="d2l_1_336_327_MarkAllUnread" class="d2l-contextmenu-item">
																						<a role="menuitem" tabindex="-1" class="d2l_1_69_361 vui-dropdown-menu-item-link"><span>Mark All Posts as Unread</span></a>
																					</li>
																					<li role="presentation" id="d2l_1_336_327_FlagThread" class="d2l-contextmenu-item">
																						<a role="menuitem" tabindex="-1" class="d2l_1_611_264 vui-dropdown-menu-item-link"><span>Flag Thread</span></a>

																					</li>
																					<li role="separator" class="d2l-contextmenu-separator"></li>

																					</li>
																					<li role="separator" class="d2l-contextmenu-separator"></li>
																					<li role="presentation" id="d2l_1_336_327_PrintThread" class="d2l-contextmenu-item">
																						<a target="_blank" role="menuitem" tabindex="-1" class="d2l_1_617_821 d2l-newwindow vui-dropdown-menu-item-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1446254/Print"><span>Print Thread</span></a>
																					</li>
																				</ul>
																			</div><div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Nathaniel Wong posted Sep 18, 2016 10:40 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_340_809">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_339_111"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_890_722" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",89)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Malware Detection ANN">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_891_105" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",90)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Malware Detection ANN">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_341_59">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_892_169" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><ol>
<li>Importance/Research</li>
</ol>
<p>As society becomes more dependent on technology, the cybersecurity
risks are growing exponentially. In a study run by Momentum Partners,
organisations spent $77 Billion on cybersecurity products in 2015. On
top of that, they spent another $491 Billion recovering from successful
cyber attacks. [1]</p>
<p>Current antivirus systems work by detecting malware based on already
known virus patterns. However, in the case of a new vulnerability that
has not yet been encountered, called a zero-day exploit, there is very
little a company can do to protect themselves [2].</p>
<p>This can be solved by training an artificial neural network with
inputs from Portable Executable (PE) Structure of executable files.
Learning from the training data, an ANN can identify if the file is
malicious or legitimate without having to execute it [3]. Being able to
detect a zero-day exploit makes malware detection much more proactive
and could save billions of dollars.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Dataset</li>
</ol>
<p>The inputs needed for the neural network training are the various
fields of Portable Executable Structure. OffensiveComputing.net has a
recently obtained dataset that contains more than half a million
malicious executables that can be used [4].</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Algorithm</li>
</ol>
<p>Since no prior knowledge of what data is distinctive for malware, an
unsupervised learning algorithm, specifically a Self-Organising Map
(SOM) like Kohonen would be used [3]. This would entail using
competitive learning, in which output neurons compete against each other
 to be activated [5]. This is opposed to using error-correction (eg.
backpropagation).</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>References</li>
</ol>
<p>[1] <a rel="noopener" href="http://momentum.partners/docs/Cybersecurity_Market_Review_Q4_2015.pdf">http://momentum.partners/docs/Cybersecurity_Market_Review_Q4_2015.pdf</a></p>
<p>[2] <a rel="noopener" href="https://www.sans.org/reading-room/whitepapers/bestprac/defenses-zero-day-exploits-various-sized-organizations-35562">https://www.sans.org/reading-room/whitepapers/bestprac/defenses-zero-day-exploits-various-sized-organizations-35562</a></p>
<p>[3] <a rel="noopener" href="http://research.ijcaonline.org/volume84/number5/pxc3892695.pdf">http://research.ijcaonline.org/volume84/number5/pxc3892695.pdf</a></p>
<p>[4] <a rel="noopener" href="http://homepage.cs.uiowa.edu/%7Emshafiq/files/vb09-zubair.pdf">http://homepage.cs.uiowa.edu/~mshafiq/files/vb09-zubair.pdf</a></p>
<p>[5] <a rel="noopener" href="http://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/%7Ejxb/NN/l16.pdf">http://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~jxb/NN/l16.pdf</a></p></div>

															<div class="d2l-le-disc-post d2l-le-disc-post-border d2l-le-disc-post-unread d2l_1_603_166" data-postid="4518101" data-contextmenuid="postContextMenu_4518101" data-postunreadtextid="postUnread_4518101" data-contentsplaceholderid="threadListItemContents_1446244">
																<div class="d2l-le-disc-posrev">
																	<div>
																		<div class="d2l-hidden">
																			<span class="d2l-fragment"><a style="top: -44px;" name="" tabindex="-1"></a></span>

																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1446244/View" title="Handwritten Chinese Character Recognition using CNN">Handwritten Chinese Character Recognition using CNN</a>
																				</h2>

																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-offscreen">Contains unread posts</div>
																			<a href="javascript:void(0);" id="d2l_1_345_384" class="d2l-contextmenu-ph d2l-left" data-contextmenuid="d2l_1_346_778" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" title="Actions for Handwritten Chinese Character Recognition using CNN" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",91)();return false;'>
																				<img src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" class="d2l_1_73_234" alt="">
																				<span class="d2l-offscreen">Actions for Handwritten Chinese Character Recognition using CNN</span>
																			</a>
																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_894_595" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">
																				<ul role="presentation" id="d2l_1_346_778" class="d2l-contextmenu">

																						<a role="menuitem" tabindex="-1" class="d2l_1_67_164 vui-dropdown-menu-item-link"><span>Mark All Posts as Read</span></a>
																					</li>
																					<li role="presentation" id="d2l_1_346_778_MarkAllUnread" class="d2l-contextmenu-item">

																					</li>

																			</div><div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Andi Geng posted Sep 18, 2016 10:37 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_350_686">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_349_545"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_901_976" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",92)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Handwritten Chinese Character Recognition using CNN">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_902_652" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",93)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Handwritten Chinese Character Recognition using CNN">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_351_955">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_903_839" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><strong>Handwritten Chinese Character Recognition using CNN</strong></p>
<p><u>Project Idea</u></p>
<p>There has been a large amount of research and effort put into digit
and word recognition using neural networks. Creating a classifier for
the MNIST dataset (handwritten characters) has become a popular
introduction to neural networks, serving as the equivalent of “Hello
World” in the deep learning community.</p>
<p>Recognizing Chinese characters presents a significantly larger
challenge than traditional English handwritten characters. For one, to
be fluent in Chinese one needs to know well over 4,000 words (with each
of them being unique) whereas in the English alphabet there are only 26
characters. The Chinese words are also much more visually complex than
English characters, often being comprised of many more strokes and lines
 than their English counterparts.</p>
<p>Current research in Chinese OCR achieves state of the art performance
 by taking advantage of domain knowledge as to how Chinese characters
are written [1] (for example, Chinese characters are largely drawn with
only 8 different directional strokes [2]). In addition, they also take
advantage of preprocessing data to artificially increase the size of the
 training set (using deformation, affine transformations, etc).</p>
<p>Practically speaking, Mandarin Chinese is the most widely spoken
language in the world, and improved OCR could help expedite the digital
preservation of one the world’s largest and most rich cultures.</p>
<p><u>Project Data</u></p>
<p>There is a huge amount of data to be used for handwritten Chinese
recognition – namely the CASIA database, which contains over 7,000
different characters and 3.9 million pieces of data [3]. We can also
artificially increase the training data by randomly shifting the images
around, warping the images slightly, applying slight tilts, and a
multitude of other transformations to improve prediction accuracy.</p>
<p>Practically speaking however, we will not be able to use all of this
data because we do not have the processing power required. We could
limit ourselves to a smaller number of classes (perhaps the most common
500 words), and experiment with different architectures with smaller
amounts of data at a time. The project would be more focused on finding
optimal performance among a smaller number of classes, and the primary
goal would be finding an architecture that is best suited to this type
of problem.</p>
<p><u>Implementation Ideas</u></p>
<p>It seems that deep convolutional neural networks using
back-propagation will yield good results. The state of the art results
are obtained using the same methodology, and CNNs seem to naturally
excel at vision related tasks [4].</p>
<p>As a team, we can decide to narrow down the number of Chinese words
that we choose to use to help find the best architecture (depth, number
of nodes, preprocessing of data, etc). This will allow us to iterate
through many different types of models to try to find a good
configuration, after which we can then configure and train on a larger
portion of the data.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><u>Citations</u></p>
<p>[1] <a rel="noopener" href="https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1505/1505.07675.pdf">https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1505/1505.07675.pdf</a></p>
<p>[2] <a rel="noopener" href="http://hub.hku.hk/bitstream/10722/53608/1/122264.pdf?accept=1">http://hub.hku.hk/bitstream/10722/53608/1/122264.pdf?accept=1</a></p>
<p>[3] <a rel="noopener" href="http://www.nlpr.ia.ac.cn/databases/handwriting/Home.html">http://www.nlpr.ia.ac.cn/databases/handwriting/Home.html</a></p>
<p>[4] <a rel="noopener" href="http://cs231n.github.io/convolutional-networks/">http://cs231n.github.io/convolutional-networks/</a></p></div>
																				</div>
																			</div><div style="background: transparent linear-gradient(to bottom, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0) 0%, rgb(255, 255, 255) 100%) repeat scroll 0% 0%; display: inherit;" class="vui-moreless-blur"></div><div style="display: inherit;" aria-hidden="true" class="vui-moreless-link" tabindex="0"><span class="vui-icon-moreless-chevron-down"></span>more</div>

															<div class="d2l-le-disc-post d2l-le-disc-post-border d2l-le-disc-post-unread d2l_1_603_166" data-postid="4518075" data-contextmenuid="postContextMenu_4518075" data-postunreadtextid="postUnread_4518075" data-contentsplaceholderid="threadListItemContents_1446232">
																<div class="d2l-le-disc-posrev">

																		<div class="d2l-inline">
																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1446232/View" title="Optimizing Athlete Selection for Teams Under a Finite Budget">Optimizing Athlete Selection for Teams Under a Finite Budget</a>
																				</h2>
																			</div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-offscreen">Contains unread posts</div>
																			<a href="javascript:void(0);" id="d2l_1_355_603" class="d2l-contextmenu-ph d2l-left" data-contextmenuid="d2l_1_356_744" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" title="Actions for Optimizing Athlete Selection for Teams Under a Finite Budget" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",94)();return false;'>
																				<img src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" class="d2l_1_73_234" alt="">
																				<span class="d2l-offscreen">Actions for Optimizing Athlete Selection for Teams Under a Finite Budget</span>
																			</a>
																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_905_383" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">
																				<ul role="presentation" id="d2l_1_356_744" class="d2l-contextmenu">

																					</li>

																			</div><div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Kevin Rush posted Sep 18, 2016 10:30 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_360_191">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_359_801"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_912_515" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",95)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Optimizing Athlete Selection for Teams Under a Finite Budget">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_913_233" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",96)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Optimizing Athlete Selection for Teams Under a Finite Budget">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_361_823">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_914_810" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><div style="direction: ltr;border-width: 100%;">
<div style="direction: ltr;margin-top: 0in;margin-left: 0in;width: 7.6041in;">
<div style="direction: ltr;margin-top: 0in;margin-left: 0in;width: 7.6041in;">
<p style="margin: 0in;font-family: Calibri;"><span style="font-size: 13.0pt;">Professional
 sports are a big part of many countries ranging from
semi-pro/professional leagues to worldwide competitions like the
Olympics or Wold Cups. Regardless of the level of play coaches are
attempting to put together the best team with the athletes presented. My
 idea is to use an ANN to be used to help the coaches in making
decisions on which athletes should be selected for the team. I think
this is important because sports are a very big part of our culture and
they have a very big economic influence which makes them a very
important aspect of our society, but a major challenge is putting
together the best team under a budget. Therefore, using a ANN would be a
 great way to try to optimize the performance of any sports team/club. I
 have read a few articles on using an ANN in making predictions on an
athlete's performance in sports and there was even one where an ANN was
used to try to assemble a cricket team. The article said that they
proposed a novel gene representation scheme and a multi-objective
approach using the NSGA-II algorithm to optimize the overall batting and
 bowling strength of the team. The article can be found here: </span><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S095741740800420X"><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S095741740800420X</span></a><span style="font-size: 11.0pt;">. </span></p>
<p style="margin: 0in;font-family: Calibri;font-size: 13.0pt;">&nbsp;</p>
<p style="margin: 0in;font-family: Calibri;font-size: 13.0pt;">Depending on the sport there are different data sets to be considered:</p>
<p style="margin: 0in;font-family: Calibri;font-size: 13.0pt;">&nbsp;</p>
<p style="margin: 0in;font-family: Calibri;font-size: 13.0pt;">For the
NFL, NHL, NBA, etc. which hold combines there is plenty of data to be
considered from the atheltes performance on different tests (40 yard
dash, vertical, bench press, etc)</p>
<ol style="margin-left: .375in;direction: ltr;unicode-bidi: embed;margin-top: 0in;margin-bottom: 0in;font-family: Calibri;font-size: 11.0pt;font-weight: normal;font-style: normal;" type="1">
<li value="1" style="margin-top: 0;margin-bottom: 0;vertical-align: middle;"><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.pensionplanpuppets.com/2016/6/5/11861154/2016-nhl-scouting-combine-complete-fitness-testing-results"><span style="font-family: Calibri;font-size: 11.0pt;">http://www.pensionplanpuppets.com/2016/6/5/11861154/2016-nhl-scouting-combine-complete-fitness-testing-results</span></a></li>
<li style="margin-top: 0;margin-bottom: 0;vertical-align: middle;"><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.pro-football-reference.com/play-index/nfl-combine-results.cgi?request=1&amp;year_min=2016&amp;year_max=2016&amp;height_min=65&amp;height_max=82&amp;weight_min=149&amp;weight_max=375&amp;pos=QB&amp;pos=WR&amp;pos=TE&amp;pos=RB&amp;pos=FB&amp;pos=OT&amp;pos=OG&amp;pos=C&amp;pos=DE&amp;pos=DT&amp;pos=ILB&amp;pos=OLB&amp;pos=SS&amp;pos=FS&amp;pos=CB&amp;pos=LS&amp;pos=K&amp;pos=P&amp;show=all&amp;order_by=year_id"><span style="font-family: Calibri;font-size: 11.0pt;">http://www.pro-football-reference.com/play-index/nfl-combine-results.cgi?request=1&amp;year_min=2016&amp;year_max=2016&amp;height_min=65&amp;height_max=82&amp;weight_min=149&amp;weight_max=375&amp;pos=QB&amp;pos=WR&amp;pos=TE&amp;pos=RB&amp;pos=FB&amp;pos=OT&amp;pos=OG&amp;pos=C&amp;pos=DE&amp;pos=DT&amp;pos=ILB&amp;pos=OLB&amp;pos=SS&amp;pos=FS&amp;pos=CB&amp;pos=LS&amp;pos=K&amp;pos=P&amp;show=all&amp;order_by=year_id</span></a></li>
<li style="margin-top: 0;margin-bottom: 0;vertical-align: middle;"><a rel="noopener" href="http://stats.nba.com/draftcombine/#%21/"><span style="font-family: Calibri;font-size: 11.0pt;">http://stats.nba.com/draftcombine/#!/</span></a></li>
</ol>
<p style="margin: 0in;font-family: Calibri;font-size: 13.0pt;">For other sports such as swimming data needs to be collected.</p>
<ol style="margin-left: .375in;direction: ltr;unicode-bidi: embed;margin-top: 0in;margin-bottom: 0in;font-family: Calibri;font-size: 11.0pt;font-weight: normal;font-style: normal;" type="1">
<li value="1" style="margin-top: 0;margin-bottom: 0;vertical-align: middle;"><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/17461390200072201?needAccess=true"><span style="font-family: Calibri;font-size: 11.0pt;">http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/17461390200072201?needAccess=true</span></a></li>
<li style="margin-top: 0;margin-bottom: 0;vertical-align: middle;"><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.jssm.org/research.php?id=jssm-06-117.xml#3"><span style="font-family: Calibri;font-size: 11.0pt;">http://www.jssm.org/research.php?id=jssm-06-117.xml#3</span></a></li>
</ol>
<p style="margin: 0in;font-family: Calibri;font-size: 11.0pt;">&nbsp;</p>
</div>
</div>
</div></div>
																				</div>

																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_924_87" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",99)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Pedestrian Vehicle Tracking and Surveying using ANN">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>

																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_371_836">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_925_453" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Idea</strong></span></p>
<p>Using Artificial Neural Networks, we can teach a computer to
distinguish pedestrians from cyclists to cars from trucks and taxies
eliminating the need for a human to stand with a clipboard at the side
of a road surveying large amounts of traffic. Because humans can only
track so many objects at once they are very inaccurate when it comes to
even the basic counting of passing cars on a highway. Using the learned
characteristics of each vehicles shape size and behavior we can make an
ANN that will more accurately count and survey large areas with the use
of cheap camera equipment while keeping surveyor humans out of harms way
 off the highways and roads.</p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Data</strong></span></p>
<p>We can use live datasets such as camera feeds from around the world
from highways or make simple data set tests by recording traffic for a
given time at a known location.</p>
<p><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.edmontontrafficcam.com/">http://www.edmontontrafficcam.com/</a></p>
<p><a rel="noopener" href="http://traffic.ottawa.ca/map/">http://traffic.ottawa.ca/map/</a></p>
<p>Some of these sets are not as fast at updating but with communication to the networks a faster refresh rate may be possible.</p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Algorithms and Methods</strong></span></p>
<p>By taking multiple images as history we can find the background model
 among them and teach the ANN to recognize the differences between the
background and the objects moving through known as Background
subtraction algorithm. Furthermore, through out the day the algorithm
will also learn how shadows and lighting conditions affect the
background subtractions. By using multiple cameras, we can teach the
system to detect flat shadows and discern them from the dimensional
objects in the stream of data. The errors would be detected when a
camera loses position of an object and later finds it again in the
middle of the frame. Because everything has to enter from the sides of
the frame and can’t just appear the system will retrace where the object
 came from and learn from why it lost tracking of it earlier.</p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>References:</strong></span></p>
<p><a rel="noopener" href="http://home.isr.uc.pt/%7Ecpremebida/files_cp/A%20Lidar%20and%20Vision-based%20Approach%20for%20Pedestrian%20and%20Vehicle%20Detection%20and%20Tracking.pdf">http://home.isr.uc.pt/~cpremebida/files_cp/A%20Lidar%20and%20Vision-based%20Approach%20for%20Pedestrian%20and%20Vehicle%20Detection%20and%20Tracking.pdf</a></p>
<p><a rel="noopener" href="http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/892151/">http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/892151/</a></p>
<p><a rel="noopener" href="http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/1505106/">http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/1505106/</a></p>
<p><a rel="noopener" href="http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11263-006-9038-7">http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11263-006-9038-7</a></p>
<p><a rel="noopener" href="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.36.2359&amp;rep=rep1&amp;type=pdf">http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.36.2359&amp;rep=rep1&amp;type=pdf</a></p></div>

																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Tiffany Leung posted Sep 18, 2016 10:21 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_380_518">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_379_134"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_934_449" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",101)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Artificial Neural Networks for the Diagnosis and Classification of Schizophrenia">

																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_935_730" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",102)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Artificial Neural Networks for the Diagnosis and Classification of Schizophrenia">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>

																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_381_374">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_936_78" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><u><span>Artificial Neural Network for The Diagnosis and Classification of Schizophrenia </span></u><span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<ol>
<li><span>What to do and why it is important. Describe existing work done on the topic and provide a list of references</span></li>
</ol>
<p><strong><span>What to do:</span></strong></p>
<p>ANNs can be used for the diagnosis and classification of Schizophrenia psychiatric disorders.<strong><span>&nbsp;
 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;
&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;</span></strong></p>
<p><strong><span>Why it’s important: </span></strong></p>
<p>ANNs have enormous potential in the diagnosis and classification of
psychiatric disorders. Current diagnostic systems rely on probabilities
or rules that struggle with the inconsistency found in clinical data due
 to imprecise patient histories and variations in symptom clusters and
clinical findings [1]. However, ANNs can identify and characterize
discriminating patterns in inconsistent and incomplete data sets. ANN
provides a model that captures the complexity of the human mind stemming
 not from the activity of single neurones, but rather from the
interactions, or microcircuits, that these cells form [1].</p>
<p><strong>Existing work: </strong></p>
<ul>
<li>ANN of cortical processing to provide a framework .for understanding pathological processes in schizophrenia [2].</li>
<li>ANN of psychiatric symptom recognition to illustrate the deficiency
of traditional algorithmic models of psychiatric diagnoses [3].</li>
<li>ANN simulation illustrating the structure of the relationships among
 situation, behavior, and childhood experience in order to predict
personality traits [4].</li>
<li>Use of ANN modeling as a diagnostic test to predict the admission decision among psychiatric emergency patients [5].</li>
<li>Use of an ANN to predict length of hospital stay given psychiatric
diagnoses, demographics, illness severity, and other predictors [6].</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong> </strong><strong><span>Data to be used. You can use data
from your other studies and course works. For ANN the more data you have
 the better the system will work</span></strong></li>
</ol>
<p><span>We can use data from existing ANN studies on Schizophrenia such
 as a Malaysian study, which collected 2 ml of peripheral venous blood
from 846 individuals for genotyping. We will study the genomic DNA and
look for deviation of allele and genotype frequencies [7]. </span><span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<ol start="3">
<li><strong> </strong><strong><span>A very high level idea about the ANN
 or the optimization algorithm (simulated annealing/ genetic algorithm)
to be used based on your reading</span></strong></li>
</ol>
<p><span>We will use multilayered perceptions and backpropagation networks.</span>
 Existing studies commonly use a single backpropagation ANN. However, it
 has been suggested that systems using ANNs in series and/or parallel
and that combine the strengths of supervised ANNs with those of
conventional statistics [8] or unsupervised network analysis [9] will
improve accuracy even further.</p>
<p><strong>References: </strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Galletly, C. A., C. Clark R., and A. Mcfarlane C. "Artificial Neural
 Networks and Psychiatric Disorders." The British Journal of Psychiatry
169.6 (1996): n. pag. Web.</li>
</ol>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Chen, E. Y. H. (1994). A neural network model of cortical
information processing in schizophrenia. 1: Interaction between
biological and social factors in symptom formation. Canadian Journal of
Psychiatry, 39, 362-367.</li>
</ol>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Berries, G. E., &amp; Chen, E. Y. H. (1993). Recognizing psychiatric
 symptoms. Relevance to the diagnostic process. British Journal of
Psychiatry, 163, 308-314.</li>
</ol>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Gonzalez-Heydrich, I. (1993). Using neural networks to model personality development. Medical Hypotheses, 41, 123-130.</li>
</ol>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Somoza, E., &amp; Somoza, J. R. (1993). A neural-network approach to
 predicting admission decisions in a psychiatric emergency room. Medical
 Decision Making, 13, 273-280.</li>
</ol>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>Davis, G. E., Walter, E. L., &amp; Davis, G. L. (1993). A neural
network that predicts psychiatric length of stay. Clinical Computing,
10, 87-92.</li>
</ol>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>Loh, Han Chern. "A Novel Approach to Predict Schizophrenia Disease:
Conceptual Framework." AMM Applied Mechanics and Materials284-287
(2013): 1596-600. Web.</li>
</ol>
<p><span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<ol start="8">
<li>Katz S, Katz AS, Lowe N, Quijano RC. 1994. Neural netbootstrap
hybrid methods for prediction of complications in patients implanted
with artificial heart valves. J Heart Valve Dis 3:49-52.</li>
</ol>
<p><span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<ol start="9">
<li>Cho S, Reggia JA. 1993. Multiple disorder diagnosis with adaptive competitive neural networks. Artif Intell Med 5:469-87.</li>
</ol>
<p><span>&nbsp;</span></p></div>

																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_946_589" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",105)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Training Neural Networks Using Genetic Algorithms">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_391_274">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_947_935" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p>Neural networks are a
 powerful classification tool. However, despite the compelling arguments
 for using neural networks as a general template for solving machine
learning problems, the training of these models and design of the right
network for a given task has been filled with many theoretical gaps and
practical concerns. [1] For example, choosing the initial parameters
(number of layers, number of batches, etc.) of a neural network for a
particular problem can involve a considerable amount of guesswork. Using
 a genetic algorithm to perform feature selection for a neural network
would increase the efficiency of the final neural network by finding the
 optimal set of initial parameters. [3]</p>
<p>The data set that will be used to train the Neural Network that will
have its initial parameters chosen by the genetic algorithm will be the
MNIST dataset from the Yann Lecunn website. [2]</p>
<p>The Neural network will be a two layer feedforward artificial neural
network perceptron trained using a sigmoid activation function and
backpropagation for weight updating. The genetic algorithm will work as
follows: a population of “chromosomes” (a set of initial parameters for a
 FFP) will be initialized that will be rated with an evaluation function
 (to be determined at a later stage of the project). The set of
chromosomes will then “reproduced” based on their evaluation
performance. The “children” of the “paired” chromosomes will then be
evaluated and reproduced. [3]</p>
<table width="100%">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="1%">
<p>[1]</p>
</td>
<td>
<p>D. J. M. a. L. Davis, "Training Feedforward Neural Networks Using Genetic Algorithms," in <em>International Joint Conferences on Artificial Intelligence Organization</em>, Cambridge, MA, 1989.</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="1%">
<p>[2]</p>
</td>
<td>
<p>Y. LeCun, "The MNIST Database of handwritten digis," [Online].
Available: http://yann.lecun.com/exdb/mnist/. [Accessed 18 September
2016].</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="1%">
<p>[3]</p>
</td>
<td>
<p>X. G. V. K. M. M. S. Y. Corinna Cortes, "AdaNet: Adaptive Structual Learning of Artificial Neural Networks," 2016.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>&nbsp;</p></div>

																		<div class="d2l-inline">
																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1446165/View" title="Predicting Diabetes Mellitus via ANNs">Predicting Diabetes Mellitus via ANNs</a>
																				</h2>
																			</div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-offscreen">Contains unread posts</div>
																			<a href="javascript:void(0);" id="d2l_1_395_984" class="d2l-contextmenu-ph d2l-left" data-contextmenuid="d2l_1_396_921" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" title="Actions for Predicting Diabetes Mellitus via ANNs" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",106)();return false;'>
																				<img src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" class="d2l_1_73_234" alt="">
																				<span class="d2l-offscreen">Actions for Predicting Diabetes Mellitus via ANNs</span>
																			</a>
																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_949_783" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">
																				<ul role="presentation" id="d2l_1_396_921" class="d2l-contextmenu">

																					</li>

																			</div><div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Anastasiya Tarnouskaya posted Sep 18, 2016 9:58 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_400_708">
																				<img title="Last edited: Sunday, September 18, 2016 10:12 PM EDT" class="d2l-image d2l_1_768_421 d2l-left d2l_1_769_495" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt="Last edited: Sunday, September 18, 2016 10:12 PM EDT">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_399_3"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_956_937" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",107)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Predicting Diabetes Mellitus via ANNs">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_957_112" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",108)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Predicting Diabetes Mellitus via ANNs">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_401_612">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_958_752" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p class="p1"><em><span class="s1">(1) Idea &amp; Importance</span></em></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Diabetes Mellitus is a chronic, life-long
 disease in which a person’s body is not able to effectively regulate
its blood sugar. This disease results in high blood sugar levels and can
 eventually cause serious long-term complications, including heart
disease, high blood pressure, eye and dental problems [1]. This is
particularly concerning considering that one in every ten people in
North America have diabetes [2] and that approximately a quarter of
those afflicted are not aware that they have the disease, as indicated
by the National Diabetes Statistics report, which states that 27.8% of
the people with diabetes in the United States are undiagnosed [3]. Since
 diabetes is a condition that can be managed to prevent some of its more
 serious complications through a healthy lifestyle [4], it is important
that people are aware of their risk-level for the onset of the disease.
As such, my idea is to use an artificial neural network (ANN) to predict
 whether a person is at a high risk for the onset of the
disease.&nbsp;The validity of this approach is supported by a similar
machine learning approach using ADAP neural networks which has already
demonstrated that neural networks are a viable way to approach this
classification problem [5].</span></p>
<p class="p1"><em><span class="s1">(2) Data Source</span></em></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">An example dataset that could be used to
effectively train an ANN for predicting whether a person is likely to
have diabetes mellitus is the&nbsp;Pima Indians Diabetes Database which
can be downloaded from the UCI Machine Learning Repository website [6].
This dataset has data from 768 patients and is broken up into nine
attributes that include information such as a patient’s blood glucose
level, blood pressure, BMI, diabetes pedigree information and a class
variable that denotes whether the patient has diabetes [6]. Although a
limitation of this dataset is that it only includes data from people of
Pima Indian heritage, it has sufficient data and few missing values,
making it is an excellent starting point for classifying patients as
being at high-, or low-risk for having diabetes mellitus.&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="p1"><em><span class="s1">(3) Algorithm</span></em></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">A multi-layer ANN would be used for this
dataset to classify patients as being at either high-, or low-risk for
having diabetes mellitus. The ANN would be trained on all attributes
except for the class variable, which is a binary attribute that denotes
whether a patient has diabetes and would be used as the output for the
classification. The ANN would learn to classify patients’ risk-level
(high or low, equivalent to the 1 or 0 class label in the dataset) via
backpropogation. Lastly, cross-validation would be used to increase the
robustness of the ANN model.</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1"></span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">[1] &nbsp;<span>What Is Diabetes Mellitus: Symptoms &amp; Treatment | Cleveland Clinic. (2013, April 4). Retrieved September 18, 2016,&nbsp;</span></span><span class="s1">from&nbsp;<a rel="noopener" href="http://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases_conditions/hic_Diabetes_Basics/hic_Diabetes_Mellitus_An_Overview">http://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases_conditions/hic_Diabetes_Basics/hic_Diabetes_Mellitus_An_Overview</a></span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">[2] &nbsp;One adult in ten has diabetes in North America. (2014, November 11). Retrieved September 18, 2016, from <a rel="noopener" href="https://www.idf.org/sites/default/files/attachments/NAC-Press-Release-WDD.pdf">https://www.idf.org/sites/default/files/attachments/NAC-Press-Release-WDD.pdf</a></span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">[3] &nbsp;2014 National Diabetes Statistics Report. (2015, May 15). Retrieved September 18, 2016, from <a rel="noopener" href="http://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/data/statistics/2014statisticsreport.html">http://www.cdc.gov/diabetes/data/statistics/2014statisticsreport.html</a></span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">[4] &nbsp;Managing Weight &amp; Diabetes. (n.d.). Retrieved September 18, 2016, from <a rel="noopener" href="http://www.diabetes.ca/diabetes-and-you/healthy-living-resources/weight-management/managing-weight-diabetes">http://www.diabetes.ca/diabetes-and-you/healthy-living-resources/weight-management/managing-weight-diabetes</a></span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1"><span>[5] &nbsp;Smith, J. W., Everhart,
J., Dickson, W., Knowler, W., &amp; Johannes, R. (1988, November 09).
Using the ADAP Learning Algorithm to Forecast the Onset of Diabetes
Mellitus. Retrieved September 18, 2016, from </span><a rel="noopener" href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2245318/">http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2245318/</a></span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">[6] &nbsp;</span>UCI Machine Learning Repository: Data Set. (2011, February 28). Retrieved September 18, 2016, from <a rel="noopener" href="http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Pima%20Indians%20Diabetes" target="_blank">http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Pima%20Indians%20Diabetes</a></p>
<p class="p1"></p></div>

																			</div>

																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Guang Yu Song posted Sep 18, 2016 9:55 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_410_633">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_409_193"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_967_471" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",110)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from ANNs in Exchange Rate Forecasting / Currency Prediction">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_968_782" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",111)();return false;' title="Subscribe to ANNs in Exchange Rate Forecasting / Currency Prediction">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_411_392">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_969_80" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><span><b>What to do and why it is important?</b></span></p>
<p><span>The exchange rate is the value of one country’s currency in
relation to another currency.&nbsp; Exchange rates fluctuate due to
differentials in inflation, interest rates, and debt.&nbsp; Each
country’s political and economic performances also plays a part in
influencing their foreign exchange rates.&nbsp; Due to the
unavailability of complete information from the past behaviour of
financial markets to fully capture the dependency between future and
past prices, the historical data’s role in the prediction process is
unrivalled[1].&nbsp; By applying artificial neural networks (ANN), it
may be possible to detect non-linear patterns and estimate relationships
 between exchange rate movements and the driving variables[2].</span></p>
<p><span></span></p>
<p><span><b>Data to be used</b></span></p>
<p><span>Official data can be obtained from the International Monetary Fund archives. <a rel="noopener" href="https://www.imf.org/external/np/fin/data/param_rms_mth.aspx"><span>https://www.imf.org/external/np/fin/data/param_rms_mth.aspx</span></a>&nbsp;
 However, there are numerous other places to find data, depending on the
 number of countries involved.&nbsp; It is especially important to take
note of factors such as warfare, disease, and other disasters that has
may significantly impact the exchange rates.</span></p>
<p><span></span></p>
<p><span><b>A very high level idea about the ANN or optimization algorithm</b></span></p>
<p><span>The project would use an enhanced MIA-GMDH-type network.&nbsp;
Experiments would include exchange rate prediction and hedging case
study.&nbsp; Group Method of Data Handling(GMDH) Framework will be used
to identify relations in large complex non-linear multidimensional
systems[3].&nbsp; Each layer will consist of simple nodes, that will
perform individualized polynomial transfer functions which would output
to nodes in the next layer.&nbsp; The output of the last layer will be a
 single node, much like the human brain.&nbsp; After computing the
optimum partial descriptions, the intermediate variables will be
selected and the multi-layered iterative computation will eventually be
stopped.</span></p>
<p><span></span></p>
<p><span><b>References</b></span></p>
<p><span>[1] Philip, A.A., Tofiki, A.A., Bidemi, A.A.: Artificial Neural
 Network Model for Forecasting Foreign Exchange Rate. World of Computer
Science and Information Technology Journal&nbsp;1(3), 110–118 (2011)</span></p>
<p><span>[2] N. Gradojevic, J. Yang, The application of artificial
neural networks to exchange rate forecasting: the role of market
microstructure variables, Working Paper 2000-23, ISSN 1192-5434, Bank of
 Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, 2000.</span></p>
<p><span>[3] TAUSER, J., BURYAN, P., 2011: Exchange Rate Predictions in
International Financial Management by Enhanced GMDH Algorithm. Prague
Economic Papers, vol. 16, no. 3, pp. 232–249.</span></p></div>
																				</div>

													<div class="d2l-datalist-item-content">
														<div aria-live="assertive" id="threadListItemContents_1446153" class="d2l-placeholder d2l-placeholder-inner d2l-placeholder-live">
															<div class="d2l-le-disc-post d2l-le-disc-post-border d2l-le-disc-post-unread d2l_1_603_166" data-postid="4517929" data-contextmenuid="postContextMenu_4517929" data-postunreadtextid="postUnread_4517929" data-contentsplaceholderid="threadListItemContents_1446153">
																<div class="d2l-le-disc-posrev">
																	<div>
																		<div class="d2l-hidden">
																			<span class="d2l-fragment"><a style="top: -44px;" name="" tabindex="-1"></a></span>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-inline">
																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1446153/View" title="Electrical Load Forecasting Using ANNs">Electrical Load Forecasting Using ANNs</a>
																				</h2>
																			</div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-offscreen">Contains unread posts</div>
																			<a href="javascript:void(0);" id="d2l_1_415_816" class="d2l-contextmenu-ph d2l-left" data-contextmenuid="d2l_1_416_131" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" title="Actions for Electrical Load Forecasting Using ANNs" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",112)();return false;'>

																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_971_422" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">
																				<ul role="presentation" id="d2l_1_416_131" class="d2l-contextmenu">
