																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Kelsey Cook posted Sep 18, 2016 8:33 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_520_338">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_519_891"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_1088_293" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",143)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Use ANN to Control Prosthetic Limbs and Wheel Chairs ">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_1089_242" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",144)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Use ANN to Control Prosthetic Limbs and Wheel Chairs ">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_521_995">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_1090_973" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><h2>Project Idea and Importance</h2>
<p>Medical procedures and technology have been advancing quickly over
the last decade which has allowed for not only safer and more intricate
surgeries, but also for advancements in the area of prosthetics and
mobility aids. In the United States alone around 2.2 million people use a
 wheel chair on a daily basis, in addition to this another 6.5 million
depend on some form of mobility aid to move around such as crutches,
canes, and walkers [1]. Each year in the US it is estimated that there
are 185 000 amputations performed in hospitals, and that number is
slowly rising [2]. As of right now there are approximately 2 million
amputees living in the US many of which also use some form of mobility
aid or prosthetic limbs [3]. Research into prosthetics has shown that as
 high as 56% of upper limb amputees, and 95% of lower limb amputees use
prosthetics limbs [4]. My idea for this project is to create an ANN that
 would be able to control mobility devices or artificial limbs using the
 user’s brain activity. The ANN would be able to monitor the firing
patterns of neurons in the operator’s brain, and use those patterns to
predict what action the operator wants their device to perform. For the
sake of this project using an ANN to control prosthetic limbs would be
too difficult, however I think it would be possible to work on making a
ANN that is able to control a wheel chairs motion by using small motors
on the rear wheels that are linked to the ANN. The importance of this
project is huge, it would help so many users of mobility devices return
to a more normal state of life. For example having a wheel chair that
moves forward when all the user does is think about going forward, or a
wheel chair that turns the corner automatically when it sees the users
approaching one.</p>
<h2>Data Sources</h2>
<p>There are several different groups doing research on the electrical
signals of brain activity and the ability to use them as an interface
with computers and machines [5][6]. Studies have shown that the
electrical signals of firing neurons can be read and can be used as an
interface to computers, this is known as a BMI or a Brain-Machine
interface [5][6]. &nbsp;However, for this project I believe it would be
far too difficult to use their finding as for this project we do not
have the time nor the equipment needed to monitor the electrical signals
 in the brain. Instead I was thinking a simple computer program could be
 written that would be an on screen mapping of several neurons in the
brain which would be represented by nodes. Clicking on a node would
activate the node and would represent the electrical signal that would
be given off of a firing neuron. The ANN would then be able to learn
certain patterns of active nodes and what thoughts they represented. For
 example a specific pattern of active nodes could represent that the
users wishes to move forwards. A separate but similar pattern may
represent that the user wishes to move backwards</p>
<h2>Neural Network</h2>
<p>The ANN algorithm would begin only knowing the location in the brain
it was to be looking for activity, and would have access to information
on the direction and speed the wheel chair would be traveling at a given
 time. Each individual’s thoughts would need to be mapped differently,
so the ANN would essentially have no information at the start of the
learning process. When the wheel chair is in use the ANN will see the
brain neurons firing as well as how and where the wheel chair is being
moved. The ANN would also have remote access to the motors on the wheels
 so it can eventually control the chair. As time progressed the ANN will
 start to recognize brain patterns that happen when the wheel chair
moves. Over time the ANN will be able to learn the meanings of each
brain pattern and will be able to predict the movement of the chair that
 will follow. Once the ANN is confident that it has learned the user’s
brain patterns, once it recognizes a patterns relevant to the chair
moving it will use the motors on the chair to move it before the user
has to do anything to manually move the chair. &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;[1] “How many people use assistive devices?,” U.S National
Library of Medicine. [Online]. Available:
https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/rehabtech/conditioninfo/pages/people.aspx.
 [Accessed: 18-Sep-2016].</p>
<p>[2] “Limb Loss in the United States,” Fact Sheet: [Online].
Available:
http://www.amputee-coalition.org/fact_sheets/limbloss_us.html.
[Accessed: 18-Sep-2016]</p>
<p>[3] “Amputee Statistics You Ought to Know | AdvancedAmputees.com,”
Amputee Statistics You Ought to Know | AdvancedAmputees.com. [Online].
Available:
http://www.advancedamputees.com/amputee-statistics-you-ought-know.
[Accessed: 18-Sep-2016].</p>
<p>[4] K. A. Raichle, “Prosthesis use in persons with lower- and
upper-limb amputation,” The Journal of Rehabilitation Research and
Development JRRD, vol. 45, no. 7, pp. 961–972, Jan. 2008.</p>
<p>&nbsp;[5] M. Lebedev, “Brain-machine interfaces: an overview,” Translational Neuroscience, vol. 5, no. 1, Jan. 2014.</p>
<p>[6] B. Fabio, “Brain Computer Interfaces for communication and
control,” Front. Neurosci. Frontiers in Neuroscience, vol. 4, 1900.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1445984/View" title="Differentiating prostate cancer tissue around blood vessels using ANN">Differentiating prostate cancer tissue around blood vessels using ANN</a>
																				</h2>
																			</div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-offscreen">Contains unread posts</div>
																			<a href="javascript:void(0);" id="d2l_1_525_250" class="d2l-contextmenu-ph d2l-left" data-contextmenuid="d2l_1_526_48" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" title="Actions for Differentiating prostate cancer tissue around blood vessels using ANN" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",145)();return false;'>
																				<img src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" class="d2l_1_73_234" alt="">
																				<span class="d2l-offscreen">Actions for Differentiating prostate cancer tissue around blood vessels using ANN</span>
																			</a>
																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_1092_472" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">
																				<ul role="presentation" id="d2l_1_526_48" class="d2l-contextmenu">
																					<li role="presentation" id="d2l_1_526_48_MarkAllRead" class="d2l-contextmenu-item">
																						<a role="menuitem" tabindex="-1" class="d2l_1_67_164 vui-dropdown-menu-item-link"><span>Mark All Posts as Read</span></a>
																					</li>
																					<li role="presentation" id="d2l_1_526_48_MarkAllUnread" class="d2l-contextmenu-item">
																						<a role="menuitem" tabindex="-1" class="d2l_1_69_361 vui-dropdown-menu-item-link"><span>Mark All Posts as Unread</span></a>
																					</li>
																					<li role="presentation" id="d2l_1_526_48_FlagThread" class="d2l-contextmenu-item">

																					</li>
																				</ul>
																			</div><div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Michael Li posted Sep 18, 2016 8:28 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_530_123">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_529_293"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_1099_596" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",146)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Differentiating prostate cancer tissue around blood vessels using ANN">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_1100_782" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",147)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Differentiating prostate cancer tissue around blood vessels using ANN">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_531_961">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_1101_345" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><u>The idea </u></p>
<p>Prostate cancer (PCa) is the second cause of death from cancer in
North American male population[1]. The early diagnosis of PCa is
critical for effective treatment and positive prognosis. A promising
line of research is biomedical image analysis. Moradi et al. introduced a
 new paradigm that applies artificial neuron networks(ANN) to
ultrasound(US) time series data for tissue typing[2]. They demonstrated
that features extracted from ultrasound time course could be used for
differentiating cancerous tissue from normal tissue, yielding tissue
typing information absent in conventional single frame US image. This
ANN based non-invasive ultrasound diagnosis achieved the same degree of
accuracy compared to histological examination by experienced
pathologists[2]. &nbsp;This new paradigm using ANN to differentiate
tissue types has been successfully extended to animal and in vivo
studies [3][4].</p>
<p>Applying ANN to differentiate tissues surrounding prostate blood
vessels provides another promising venue for research.&nbsp; Blood
vessel pulsation provides a natural dynamic contrast in biological
tissue properties. In fact, PCa tissues are denser in growing new blood
vessels [5] and generally have smaller cell sizes[6]. As a result, the
mechanical perturbation of blood vessel can elicit differential
vibration response between tumor tissue and healthy tissue.&nbsp;
Therefore, I hypothesize that applying ANNs to ultrasound time series of
 tissues surrounding blood vessels would achieve better tissue typing
capability.</p>
<p><u>Data collection</u></p>
<p>For a proof of concept, the data collection has been carried out by
taking ultrasound time series data in agar based prostate mimicking
models. &nbsp;PCa tissues were modeled with smaller US scatter sizes
compared to healthy tissues. The model was also integrated with a small
pulsating tubing to simulate blood vessel vibration. Ultrasound time
series data was acquired for region of interest (ROI) selection and ANN
training.</p>
<p><u>Forward ANN with backward propagation</u></p>
<p>Biomedical image analysis based on artificial neuron network (ANN)
has great potential in diagnosing tissue types.&nbsp; The application of
 ANN in US has been used to diagnose breast nodules [7],&nbsp; determine
 blood vessel wall’s mechanical properties[8], and classify liver
disease [9]. In this project, feedforward Artificial neural networks
with backpropagation will be used to classify tissue models with
different particle sizes. ANN is a classification algorithm in which a
nonlinear function maps the input feature vectors to an output layer. It
 is a constructed with a network of nodes connected by
weights[10].&nbsp;&nbsp; The input layer to this neural network will be a
 feature vector extracted from US ROIs and the output layer consists of
two nodes, each indicating a tissue type. The ANN will be trained with
backpropagation in which the weights will be optimized to reduce the
error between training samples and the network output. &nbsp;Moradi et
al have demonstrated success with this classification scheme[2]. As a
result, ANN with backpropagation is used to classify models with
different particle sizes under simulated blood vessel perturbation.</p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;">&nbsp;Reference</span></p>
<p>[1]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; “What are the key statistics about
prostate cancer?” [Online]. Available:
http://www.cancer.org/cancer/prostatecancer/detailedguide/prostate-cancer-key-statistics.</p>
<p>[2]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; M. Moradi, “A New paradigm for Ultrasound-Based,” no. September, 2008.</p>
<p>[3]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; M. Moradi, P. Abolmaesumi, and P.
Mousavi, “Tissue typing using ultrasound RF time series: experiments
with animal tissue samples.,” <em>Med. Phys.</em>, vol. 37, no. 8, pp. 4401–4413, 2010.</p>
<p>[4]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; F. Imani, P. Abolmaesumi, E.
Gibson, A. Khojaste, M. Gaed, M. Moussa, D. R. Siemens, A. Fenster, A.
Ward, and P. Mousavi, “Computer-aided Prostate Cancer Detection Using
Ultrasound RF Time Series: In vivo Feasibility Study.,” <em>IEEE Trans. Med. Imaging</em>, vol. PP, no. 99, p. 1, 2015.</p>
<p>[5]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; I. F. Lissbrant, E. Lissbrant, J.
Damber, A. Bergh, I. F. Lissbrant, E. Lissbrant, J. Damber, and A.
Bergh, “Blood Vessels are Regulators of Growth , Diagnostic Markers and
Therapeutic Targets in Prostate Cancer Blood Vessels are Regulators of
Growth , Diagnostic Markers and Therapeutic Targets in Prostate Cancer,”
 <em>Scand. Jounrnal Urol. Nephrol.</em>, vol. 5599, no. September, 2016.</p>
<p>[6]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; V. Kumar, A. K. Abbas, J. C. Aster, and S. L. (Stanley L. Robbins, <em>Robbins basic pathology</em>. Elsevier/Saunders, 2013.</p>
<p>[7]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; S. Joo, W. K. Moon, H. C. Kim, and
I. P. E. Major, “Computer-aidied Diagnosis of Solid Breast Nodules on
Ultrasound with Digital Image Processing and Artificial Neural Network,”
 pp. 1397–1400, 2004.</p>
<p>[8]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; F. Pessana, E. Venialgo, J.
Rubstein, and A. Furfaro, “Assessment of Human Instantaneous Arterial
Diameter Using B- Mode Ultrasound Imaging and Artificial Neural
Networks: Determination of Wall Mechanical Properties,” pp. 1409–1412,
2010.</p>
<p>[9]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; R. K. K and S. Radhakrishnan,
“Focal and diffused liver disease classification from ultrasound images
based on isocontour segmentation,” no. August 2013, 2015.</p>
<p>[10]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; K. Mehrotra and C. K. Mohan, “Elements of Artificial Neural Networks.”</p></div>

																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Zachary Rose posted Sep 18, 2016 8:27 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_540_763">
																				<img title="Last edited: Sunday, September 18, 2016 8:28 PM EDT" class="d2l-image d2l_1_768_421 d2l-left d2l_1_769_495" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt="Last edited: Sunday, September 18, 2016 8:28 PM EDT">

																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_539_7"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_1110_214" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",149)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Using ANN Object Identification For Building Security (Weapon Detection)">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>

																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_1111_38" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",150)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Using ANN Object Identification For Building Security (Weapon Detection)">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>

																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_541_832">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_1112_946" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p>Using ANN Object Identification for security and safety purposes</p>
<p>What to do and why it’s important</p>
<p><br>As neural networks advance in technology and become more apparent
 in everyday life, the tasks in which they are used for becoming
increasingly more difficult. A common primary goal of an artificial
intelligence is the ability to mimic the thought process of a human, in
order to do tasks that would otherwise need to be done by a human.
Humans have the ability to tell apart the difference between a Lion and a
 Jaguar, read a sign, or recognize a human’s face. These problems are
harder to solve with a computer, as they only seem easy because our
brains are incredible good at understanding images [1]. In the past few
years, machine learning has made tremendous progress on addressing these
 difficult problems, to the point where machines can perform equal or
better than humans in visual recognition tasks in some domains. A model
used to develop these machines is the Deep Convolutional Neural Network,
 which can be thought of neural network which has many neurons and
express computationally large models while keeping the number of actual
parameters [2]. This is useful because a neural network can learn a
neuron once and use it in many places, making it easier to learn the
model and reducing error. Convolutional layers of neurons are often
interweaved with pooling layers, which aids in determine max and min
features of different pools of parameters, and which each layer, the
network can detect higher-level, more abstract features, and current
projects have been able to classify images into a thousand different
categories. Convolutional Neural Networks are currently being used for
many object detection and identification as a result of its superior
performance over other systems. One of these systems if traffic
monitoring, which is done using a low resolution camera yet still able
to have an average accuracy of 94.72% [3]. This paper discusses how
vehicle type identification is done with vehicle make and model
recognition. In the vehicle being recognized is compared with a make and
 model data set to find the type with the most similarities with the
input data, this is done with the Euclidean distance or the ordinary
distance between two points that one would measure with a ruler [3].
Based on different conditions, the recognition rate varies from around
60% to 90%. The idea of image detection may also be used on a smaller
scale. This paper reports possibility of using artificial neural
networks as a tool for classification, designed to identify apple
orchard pests. Neural modeling techniques, including digital image
analysis, were used to classify the pests [4]. In this study,
multi-layered neural network topology is used, similar to a
Convolutional Neural Network, and allows for effective pest
identification of 23 visual parameters in the shapes and colours. These
projects are important to the overall goal of using ANN object
identification for security, as different levels of image detection
neural networks combined with a large database of properties of various
categories of images can product a machine that can identify virtually
any moving object in a given area. This machine can then be used for
safety purposes, by flagging a user of dangerous or uncommonly seen
objects in an area, such as an animal or a human with a weapon.</p>
<p>Data to be used</p>
<p><br>Data will vary between current ANNs that focus on precise image
detection, and ANNs that specialize in connecting an image with various
properties, to a database of properties to alarm a user if the image
being detected is in fact dangerous or harmful. Data that would also be
used is any current security tools to help determine what certain
objects are based on specific properties of that object. A powerful and
completed piece of work that may be used is a program called
Inception-V3, which is a cutting edge image detection system that is
used to report its top 5 guesses of what a certain image is showing at
an extremely high accuracy in the high 90 percentages. This program is
available on the Image Recognition tutorial of tensor flow. In regards
to designing the machine itself and adjusting the machine to train
itself properly, a lot of work has been done by Cadence Design Systems
regarding the ANN in embedded systems, and Tensilica processors, which
is a high performance, low-power DSP specifically designed for image and
 computer Image processing [5] . There is also a significant amount of
research done regarding Algorithms for performance vs. Complexity and
the trade-off between these two major points, as well as research
regarding maximizing the training the machine put forwards, and
different types of recognition algorithms which are used to implement
data layers and pools as spoken about earlier.</p>
<p>ANN Optimization Algorithm to be Used Based on Reading</p>
<p><br>In order for image recognition to be possible, a convolutional
neural network must be used. This means multi layers of neurons will be
used to report data from various properties of an image. Alongside,
pools of data can also be used from which each pool reports the most
prominent value in the pool of data, which then gets brought to one of
the layers of neurons, which ‘cleans’ the image being modeled. Values
such as length, height, depth, ect. Can all be measured by a straight
line conversion from the data of the picture itself, and things like
colour are all represented as a combination of three basic color
components: red, green, and blue [6]. All of these properties would be
data based, and the image being modeled would try to be matched with a
data base of pre data mined objects. Each neuron would be considered a
pixel at a specific location, with all neurons being reported to
determine the final image. The algorithm would then be imported into
different applications, and troubleshooting would be reporting&nbsp;to
the machine what the actual object is after the machine out ports the
object in question, and in turn adjusting its guesses based on if it was
 previously correct or not.</p>
<p>[1] “Image Recognition,” Image Recognition. [Online]. Available:
https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.10/tutorials/image_recognition/index.html.
 [Accessed: 18-Sep-2016].</p>
<p><br>[2] “Conv Nets: A Modular Perspective,” - colah's blog,
08-Jul-2014. [Online]. Available:
http://colah.github.io/posts/2014-07-conv-nets-modular/. [Accessed:
18-Sep-2016].</p>
<p><br>[3] C. M. Bautista, C. A. Dy, M. I. Mañalac, R. A. Orbe and M.
Cordel, "Convolutional neural network for vehicle detection in low
resolution traffic videos," 2016 IEEE Region 10 Symposium (TENSYMP),
Bali, 2016, pp. 277-281. [Accessed: 18-Sep-2016].</p>
<p><br>[4] P. Boniecki, K. Koszela, H. Pierkarska-Boniecka, J. Weres, M.
 Zaborowicz, S. Kujawa, A. Majewski, B. Raba, “Neural identification of
selected apple pests,” 21-Sep-2014. [Accessed: 18-Sep-2016]</p>
<p><br>[5] S. Hijazi, C. Rowen, and R. Rowen, “Using Convolutional
Neural Networks for Image Recognition,” Cadence. [Online]. Available:
http://ip.cadence.com/uploads/901/cnn_wp-pdf. [Accessed: 18-Sep-2016].</p>
<p><br>[6] “Image Recognition with Neural Networks,” Image Recognition
with Neural Networks. [Online]. Available:
http://neuroph.sourceforge.net/image_recognition.html. [Accessed:
18-Sep-2016].</p></div>

																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_551_201">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_1123_26" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><strong>1. Project Idea / Importance</strong></p>
<p>Entering complex equations into a digital text is often quite
difficult and many basic text editors do not also contain an equation
editor. This makes&nbsp;creating equations with symbols not available on
 the standard keyboard such as a derivative or integral symbols or
equations using large operators such as a summation operator very
challenging. Character recognition using artificial neural networks [1]
has been studied frequently in the past couple of decades. Artificial
neural networks can also be used to in a similar manner to recognize
numerical digits and operators as equations made up of characters. The
characters can then be converted into electronic text so they are easier
 to view and include in documents. A software development company
MyScript implements several equation recognition apps for IOS and
android as well as web applications for windows[2]. There have also been
 many studies recently conducted on this topic. An earlier study
outlines some of the challenges associated with this one of which is
correctly partitioning an expression into separate characters [3]. To
keep the scope of the project manageable for a single semester project
only recognition of individual characters will be attempted.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>2. Data</strong></p>
<p>There are handwritten mathematical symbol data sets available online which can be used to train an artificial neural network.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>3. Algorithm</strong></p>
<p>Characters are recognized by decomposing individual characters into
strokes which create them with an input node for each defined stroke and
 output nodes for all recognizable characters [1]. This will require a
multi-layered network which uses back propagation as the control
strategy.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>[1] Rodin, E. Y., Wu, Y., &amp; Amin, S. M. (1992). Character recognition: Qualitative reasoning and neural networks.<span><em>&nbsp;</em></span><em>Mathematical and Computer Modelling,<span>&nbsp;</span>16</em>(2), 95-104. doi:10.1016/0895-7177(92)90010-I</p>
<p>[2] <a rel="noopener" href="http://myscript.com/technology/technical-demonstrations/">http://myscript.com/technology/technical-demonstrations/</a></p>
<p>[3] Matsakis, N. (1999). Recognition of Handwritten Mathematical Expressions. Master’s thesis, MIT, Cambridge</p></div>
																				</div>
																			</div><div style="background: transparent linear-gradient(to bottom, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0) 0%, rgb(255, 255, 255) 100%) repeat scroll 0% 0%; display: inherit;" class="vui-moreless-blur"></div><div style="display: inherit;" aria-hidden="true" class="vui-moreless-link" tabindex="0"><span class="vui-icon-moreless-chevron-down"></span>more</div>

																				</div>

																<div class="d2l-le-disc-posrev">

																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1445855/View" title="Predicting the Popularity of a Song or Album using ANNs">Predicting the Popularity of a Song or Album using ANNs</a>
																				</h2>
																			</div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-offscreen">Contains unread posts</div>
																			<a href="javascript:void(0);" id="d2l_1_555_778" class="d2l-contextmenu-ph d2l-left" data-contextmenuid="d2l_1_556_313" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" title="Actions for Predicting the Popularity of a Song or Album using ANNs" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",154)();return false;'>

																			</a>
																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_1125_840" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">
																				<ul role="presentation" id="d2l_1_556_313" class="d2l-contextmenu">
																					<li role="presentation" id="d2l_1_556_313_MarkAllRead" class="d2l-contextmenu-item">

																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Sam Codrington posted Sep 18, 2016 7:13 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_560_235">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_559_136"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_1132_156" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",155)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Predicting the Popularity of a Song or Album using ANNs">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_1133_268" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",156)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Predicting the Popularity of a Song or Album using ANNs">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_561_756">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_1134_833" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><strong>Predicting the Popularity of a Song or Album using ANNs</strong></p>
<p>1) The music industry is one of the largest industries in the world,
valued at over C$334 million in Canada in 2013 alone [1] and there can
be highly lucrative potential in the ability to predict the next big hit
 song. As there have been numerous studies [2] [4] demonstrating the
link between ostensibly arbitrary attributes of a song like repetitive
song lyrics, speed of tempo or volume to its enjoyment and subsequent
popularity, an artificial neural network may provide the key to turn
such an enormous amount of data into a predictor of how successful a new
 song or album will be. There have been several successful experiments
[3] [4] to create such an algorithm, as well as a similar idea proposed
by Greg Slasor below. One of those experiments [4] gave each of the top
ten hits of 2015 between a 68 and 89% probability of being a hit [5]. If
 an algorithm could be perfected it could be a lucrative tool for
recording companies to target their sales, and a viable litmus test for
the fruit of their production studios.</p>
<p>2) There are several different methods that could be used to try and
determine the popularity as and other characteristics of music. There
are several large datasets that could be harnessed [6], as well as
several websites who could have their data mined using their open source
 APIs [7] [8] to trawl for meaningful data whether it be artist, genre,
beats per minute, song length, loudness etc.</p>
<p>3) A feed forward neural network would be the approach best suited to
 taking the many inputs and finding meaningful weights for each of them.
 At first glance it would seem like a multi-layer perceptron network
would have potential (as explained by Greg Slasor below) but it would
also be possible to use the unsegmented ability of recurrent neural
networks to examine the relationship between different parts of a song
to search for clues in the architecture of the song (ie. hunting for
“drops”, catchy choruses, or specific song structure)</p>
<p><strong>References</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Stats Can Sound Recording and music publishing, revenue from sales of recordings based on musical categories :<br><a rel="noopener" href="http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/pick-choisir?lang=eng&amp;p2=33&amp;id=3610063">http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/pick-choisir?lang=eng&amp;p2=33&amp;id=3610063</a><br><br></li>
<li>The power of repetition: repetitive lyrics in a song increase processing fluency and drive market success: <a rel="noopener" href="https://msbfile03.usc.edu/digitalmeasures/jnunes/intellcont/Power%20of%20Repetition%20Final-1.pdf">https://msbfile03.usc.edu/digitalmeasures/jnunes/intellcont/Power%20of%20Repetition%20Final-1.pdf<br><br></a></li>
<li>Monterola, C., Abundo, C., Tugaff, J., &amp; Venturina, L. E.
(2009). Prediction Of Potential Hit Song And Musical Genre Using
Artificial Neural Networks.<span></span><em>Int. J. Mod. Phys. C International Journal of Modern Physics C,</em><span>&nbsp;</span><em>20</em>(11), 1697-1718. doi:10.1142/s0129183109014680</li>
</ol>
<p><span>&nbsp;</span><a rel="noopener" href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1142/S0129183109014680">http://dx.doi.org/10.1142/S0129183109014680</a></p>
<ol start="4">

Hit Song Prediction, Journal of New Music Research, 43:3, 291-302, DOI:
10.1080/09298215.2014.881888</li>
</ol>
<p><a rel="noopener" href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09298215.2014.881888">http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09298215.2014.881888</a></p>
<ol start="5">
<li><a rel="noopener" href="http://motherboard.vice.com/read/a-machine-successfully-predicted-the-hit-dance-songs-of-2015">http://motherboard.vice.com/read/a-machine-successfully-predicted-the-hit-dance-songs-of-2015</a></li>
<li><a rel="noopener" href="http://labrosa.ee.columbia.edu/millionsong/">http://labrosa.ee.columbia.edu/millionsong/</a> - Columbia University’s Data set of one million songs with data about the song title, tempo, length, etc.</li>
<li><a rel="noopener" href="https://developer.spotify.com/web-api/">https://developer.spotify.com/web-api/</a> <br> 8. <a rel="noopener" href="http://www.last.fm/api">http://www.last.fm/api</a></li>
</ol></div>

																				</h2>

																			</a>
																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_1136_466" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">

																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Alex Kenny posted Sep 18, 2016 6:44 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_570_753">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_569_792"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_1143_105" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",158)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Detecting Parkinson Disease Using Voice Analysis">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_1144_27" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",159)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Detecting Parkinson Disease Using Voice Analysis">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_571_945">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_1145_934" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Idea/Importance:</strong></span></p>
<p>Parkinson Disease affects nearly 1 million Americans with upwards of
60,000 new diagnosis each year [1] and following Alzheimer's disease is
the second most common neuro-degenerative disorder in the U.S.[2]. Many
more go without being diagnosed because the early symptoms can easily be
 mistaken for other conditions or a byproduct of growing older.
Additionally no standardized diagnostic test exists which only
exacerbates the issue of incorrect or missed diagnosis [3].<br><br>Creating
 a reliable diagnostic would significantly improve the lives of the
affected while also cutting down on the medical costs associated with
misdiagnosed patients which currently costs the U.S. alone an estimated
$25B a year [1].</p>
<p></p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Data Set:<br></strong></span><br>I
 have found a dataset created by Max Little of the University of Oxford
that is hosted and made available on the&nbsp;UC&nbsp;Irvine Machine
Learning Repository. It contains 197 instances each with
23&nbsp;attributes for classification as well as a binary representation
 of if the subject has Parkinson Disease or not. The
attributes&nbsp;have been generated based on voice analysis of speech
samples from the National Centre for Voice and Speech, Denver, Colorado.
 [4]</p>
<p></p>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Algorithm:</strong></span>&nbsp;</p>
<p>There has been success (87.7% classification rate) using feed forward
 back propagation algorithms to adjust the weighting of various transfer
 functions used for classification [5] and also various comparative
studies between &nbsp;multilayer perceptron neural networks and support
vector machines which indicate that the process has potential for
accurate and speedy classification given a large enough training sample
[6].<br><br>At a high level what this means is that we should use a feed
 forward ANN then asses the accuracy of the results using some function
(such as mean squared error) and send the results of this back to the
start to adjust the network until the best fit is achieved. Additional
steps will need to be taken to avoid over fitting and given enough time
additional effort should be put into improving the initial algorithm or
comparing it to other ANN methods to reduce runtime or increase
accuracy. &nbsp;</p>
<p><br><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>References:<br></strong></span>[1] <span class="selectable"><i>Statistics on Parkinson's - Parkinson's Disease Foundation (PDF)</i>. (2016). <i>Pdf.org</i>. Retrieved 18 September 2016, from http://www.pdf.org/en/parkinson_statistics</span></p>
<p><span class="selectable">[2] <span class="selectable"><i>NINDS | Parkinson's Disease | Challenges, Progress, and Promise</i>. (2016). <i>Ninds.nih.gov</i>. Retrieved 18 September 2016, from http://www.ninds.nih.gov/disorders/parkinsons_disease/parkinsons_research.htm</span></span></p>
<p><span class="selectable">[3] <span class="selectable"><i>NIHSeniorHealth: Parkinson's Disease - What Is Parkinson's Disease?</i>. (2016). <i>Nihseniorhealth.gov</i>. Retrieved 18 September 2016, from https://nihseniorhealth.gov/parkinsonsdisease/whatisparkinsonsdisease/01.html</span></span></p>
<p><span class="selectable"><span class="selectable"><span class="selectable">[4] <span class="selectable"><i>UCI Machine Learning Repository: Parkinsons Data Set</i>. (2016). <i>Archive.ics.uci.edu</i>. Retrieved 18 September 2016, from http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Parkinsons</span></span></span></span></p>
<p><span>[5] Saloni, R. K. Sharma, Anil K. Gupta,"Voice Analysis for
Telediagnosis of Parkinson Disease Using Artificial Neural Networks and
Support Vector Machines", IJISA, vol.7, no.6, pp.41-47, 2015. DOI:
10.5815/ijisa.2015.06.04</span></p>
<p><span>[6]&nbsp;K. Uma Rani, Mallikarjun S Holi. (Vol. 3 - Issue 4 (April- 2014) ) . " <i>A Comparative Study of Neural Networks and Support Vector Machines for Neurological Disordered Voice Classification</i><span> ", International Journal of Engineering Research &amp; Technology (IJERT) , ISSN: 2278-0181 , www.ijert.org</span></span></p></div>
																				</div>

														<div aria-live="assertive" id="threadListItemContents_1445785" class="d2l-placeholder d2l-placeholder-inner d2l-placeholder-live">
															<div class="d2l-le-disc-post d2l-le-disc-post-border d2l-le-disc-post-unread d2l_1_603_166" data-postid="4517221" data-contextmenuid="postContextMenu_4517221" data-postunreadtextid="postUnread_4517221" data-contentsplaceholderid="threadListItemContents_1445785">
																<div class="d2l-le-disc-posrev">
																	<div>
																		<div class="d2l-hidden">

																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-inline">
																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1445785/View" title="Predicting winning fantasy football line-ups">Predicting winning fantasy football line-ups</a>
																				</h2>
																			</div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-offscreen">Contains unread posts</div>
																			<a href="javascript:void(0);" id="d2l_1_575_504" class="d2l-contextmenu-ph d2l-left" data-contextmenuid="d2l_1_576_546" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" title="Actions for Predicting winning fantasy football line-ups" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",160)();return false;'>

																			</a>
																			<div tabindex="-1" role="menu" id="d2l_1_1147_68" class="d2l-floating-container vui-dropdown-menu d2l-hidden d2l-floating-container-autoclose">
																				<ul role="presentation" id="d2l_1_576_546" class="d2l-contextmenu">

																			</div><div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">John Martin posted Sep 18, 2016 6:27 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_580_499">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_579_462"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_1154_162" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",161)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Predicting winning fantasy football line-ups">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_1155_537" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",162)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Predicting winning fantasy football line-ups">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_581_632">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_1156_563" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p class="p1"><span class="s1"></span><strong><span class="s1">1. What to do and why?</span></strong></p>
<p class="p2">In recent years, online betting websites have started
offering competitions where people pay to build a fantasy team each week
 for a chance to win money against other users. The standard format for
an NFL fantasy team is to select one quarterback, two running backs, two
 wide receivers, a kicker, a tight end, and a defence. When selecting
players they can come from any team in the league, but higher value
players have a higher associated cost. Each team is limited by a 'salary
 cap'.<br><strong><span class="s1"></span></strong></p>
<p class="p2">There are many existing algorithms but the vast majority
are proprietary [1]. This is probably because of the financial value
associated with creating a reliable, winning algorithm.</p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">A technique applied by a group from
Stanford University was to use Machine Learning to predict the points
any given player will score in a week. The next step was to use convex
optimization to assemble a team that will provide maximum return based
off the cost of each player [2]. </span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">The goal of this is to prove that Machine
 Learning can be used to predict the outcome of sports games while
eliminating fans personal bias towards a team or a player.</span></p>
<p class="p1"><strong><span class="s1">2. Data to be used.</span></strong></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Luckily, fantasy sports is a billion
dollar market with fans who expect a live updates for the stats of each
player on their team. To accurately predict an individuals potential
point totals more than just individual player stats need to be examined.
 The history of the teams they played while having high and low scoring
games, as well as if a player's game was affected by injury. I will use
an open-source python module which parses data live from NFL Game
Centre. </span></p>
<p class="p2">The module can be used to collect live data and data from past seasons. It is imported in JSON format.</p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">The project is supported by over 10
developers and has almost 1000 stars on Github. It can be found here:
https://github.com/BurntSushi/nflgame</span></p>
<p class="p1"><strong><span class="s1">3. High level overview. </span></strong></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">The problem we are trying to solve is a regression problem, continuously predicting a player's stats. </span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Our first step is to generate point-total
 predictions for players at each position. Using past season's data, we
can generate a model for predicting point totals by training an ANN. The
 most effective way to create our neural network is to use our model to
generate a hypothesis across a group of players by position, rather than
 training a hypothesis for each individual player. </span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Assuming the model for predicting player
point totals holds up against live data, the last step is to create a
team optimizer. The goal of the optimizer is to correlate Salary (cost
of a player) to fantasy points per game, to see if there are any players
 that stand out for their value compared to projected points. The
optimizer can be written as a genetic algorithm, the reason for a
genetic algorithm is because it is good at handling data with a lot of
noise [3]. </span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1"></span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">[1] Dunnington, Nathan. “Fantasy Football Projection Analysis”. Honors Thesis. University of Oregon. 2015.</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Web. &lt;http://economics.uoregon.edu/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2015/03/Dunnington Thesis 2015.pdf&gt;</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">[2] Sugar, Glen. "Predicting Optimal Game Day Fantasy Football Teams". Stanford University. 2015. </span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">Web. &lt;http://cs229.stanford.edu/proj2015/115_report.pdf&gt;</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">[3] Ruths, Troy. "Draft Kings and Data Science: Double your Money, Double your Fun". Web. Data Shop Talk. 2015.</span></p>
<p class="p1"><span class="s1">&lt;http://datashoptalk.com/double-yo-money&gt;</span></p></div>
																				</div>

														<div aria-live="assertive" id="threadListItemContents_1445754" class="d2l-placeholder d2l-placeholder-inner d2l-placeholder-live">
															<div class="d2l-le-disc-post d2l-le-disc-post-border d2l-le-disc-post-unread d2l_1_603_166" data-postid="4517160" data-contextmenuid="postContextMenu_4517160" data-postunreadtextid="postUnread_4517160" data-contentsplaceholderid="threadListItemContents_1445754">

																						<a target="_blank" role="menuitem" tabindex="-1" class="d2l_1_617_821 d2l-newwindow vui-dropdown-menu-item-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1445754/Print"><span>Print Thread</span></a>
																					</li>
																				</ul>
																			</div><div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Clark Holdham posted Sep 18, 2016 6:07 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_590_444">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_589_379"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_1165_771" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",164)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Predicting Student Performance">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_1166_880" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",165)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Predicting Student Performance">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_591_772">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_1167_677" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p>1. University
admissions&nbsp;offices are burdened ever year with the task of choosing
 the best possible candidates for enrolment. Having a single person
review a students marks and potentially a short PSE may not be the best
method of predicting a students performance at the university level.
Supplying an artificial neural network with the gathered information may
 be able to better predict students performance. Beyond this, it may be
able to discover specific reasons leading to a student failure or
success.</p>
<p>2. &nbsp;The data necessary to research this ANN further should be
available through Queens in an anonymous format. Information such as
grades, school of origin and more should be available. The students PSE
may also be a valuable resource but any personal info would need to be
removed before use.</p>
<p>3. [1] Used a multi-layered feed-forward network with a Cuckoo search
 algorithm. A similar approach could be used with potentially different
search algorithms and the identification of different input variables.</p>
<p>[1]&nbsp;<span>CHEN J, DO Q. TRAINING NEURAL NETWORKS TO PREDICT
STUDENT ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE: A COMPARISON OF CUCKOO SEARCH AND
GRAVITATIONAL SEARCH ALGORITHMS. </span><i>International Journal Of Computational Intelligence &amp; Applications</i><span> [serial online]. March 2014;13(1):-1. Available from: Academic Search Complete, Ipswich, MA. Accessed September 18, 2016.</span></p>
<p><span>[2]&nbsp;<span>P. M. Arsad, N. Buniyamin and J. l. A. Manan, "A neural network students' performance prediction model (NNSPPM)," </span><em>Smart Instrumentation, Measurement and Applications (ICSIMA), 2013 IEEE International Conference on</em><span>, Kuala Lumpur, 2013, pp. 1-5.</span><br><span>doi: 10.1109/ICSIMA.2013.6717966</span><br><span>URL:&nbsp;</span><a rel="noopener" href="http://ieeexplore.ieee.org.proxy.queensu.ca/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&amp;arnumber=6717966&amp;isnumber=6717902">http://ieeexplore.ieee.org.proxy.queensu.ca/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&amp;arnumber=6717966&amp;isnumber=6717902</a></span></p>
<p><span>[3]&nbsp;<span>R. M. de Albuquerque, A. A. Bezerra, D. A. de
Souza, L. B. P. do Nascimento, J. J. d. M. Sá and J. C. do Nascimento,
"Using neural networks to predict the future performance of students," </span><em>2015 International Symposium on Computers in Education (SIIE)</em><span>, Setubal, 2015, pp. 109-113.</span><br><span>doi: 10.1109/SIIE.2015.7451658</span><br><span>URL:&nbsp;</span><a rel="noopener" href="http://ieeexplore.ieee.org.proxy.queensu.ca/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&amp;arnumber=7451658&amp;isnumber=7451633">http://ieeexplore.ieee.org.proxy.queensu.ca/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&amp;arnumber=7451658&amp;isnumber=7451633</a><br></span></p></div>

																			<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_604_734 d2l_1_605_104">
																				<h2 class="d2l-linkheading-level3 d2l-ellipsis"><a tabindex="0" class="d2l-linkheading-link d2l-clickable vui-link" href="https://onq.queensu.ca/d2l/le/56359/discussions/threads/1445751/View" title="Software Repository Feature Clustering">Software Repository Feature Clustering</a>
																				</h2>

																			<div class="d2l-textblock d2l-textblock-secondary d2l-left d2l_1_618_395">Troy Wolters posted Sep 18, 2016 6:05 PM</div>
																			<div class="d2l-left" id="d2l_1_600_663">
																				<div class="d2l-left d2l_1_619_265 d2l-inline">
																					<span tabindex="-1" class="d2l-toggle" id="d2l_1_599_251"><a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink d2l-hidden" id="d2l_1_1176_529" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",167)();return false;' title="Unsubscribe from Software Repository Feature Clustering">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_78_974" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribed</span>
																					</a>
																					<a href="javascript:void(0);" class="d2l-text-imagelink" id="d2l_1_1177_675" onclick='D2L.O("__g1",168)();return false;' title="Subscribe to Software Repository Feature Clustering">
																						<img class="d2l-text-imagelink-img d2l_1_79_606" src="Project%20Idea%20Post%20Forum%20-%20CISC_CMPE%20452_COGS%20400_CISC%20874%20-%20Neural%20and%20Genetic%20Cognitive%20Models%20F16_files/pixel.gif" alt=""><span class="d2l-text-imagelink-text">Subscribe</span>
																					</a>
																					</span></div>
																			</div>
																		</div>
																		<div class="d2l-clear"></div>
																		<div class="d2l_1_622_891" id="d2l_1_601_170">
																			<div style="line-height: normal; height: 63px;" class="vui-moreless" id="d2l_1_1178_997" data-moreless-lesstitle="less" data-moreless-moretitle="more" data-moreless-accessible="False" data-moreless-blurcolor="#FFFFFF" data-moreless-height="63px">
																				<div>
																					<div class="d2l-htmlblock"><p><strong><u>Project Idea and Importance</u></strong></p>
<p>When writing code, a programmer often comes across common problems
that can be solved by using third party libraries. To illustrate this
situation, imagine a back end developer recognizes that using templated
files will solve many problems for them. They search online for
templating libraries that fit their framework. From there, the developer
 must spend a substantial amount of time researching the different
libraries, assessing their strengths and weaknesses, and eventually come
 to a decision on which one to use. This process is time-consuming and
arduous.</p>
<p>Artificial neural networks could be used to classify software
repositories in a number of ways to make evaluation by programmers
easier. Examples of potential classifications could include programming
paradigm used, existence of comments and documentation, and style
consistency. Classifying software libraries based on their attributes is
 important because it organizes implicit information in a way that can
be easily digested by a developer, making their decision making process
easier and faster. It also has the potential to show insights into the
code that the developer might have missed if analyzing the library
manually.</p>
<p><strong><u>Data</u></strong></p>
<p>Any source code can be used to train the data. A vast amount of code
is freely available at popular online code-hosting websites such as
GitLab [1] and GitHub [2]. There are publicly available APIs for each of
 those services that would allow for automated downloading of
repositories to build up a data set. This data would be suitable for
unsupervised learning because it is unlabeled, raw source code.</p>
<p><strong><u>High-Level Algorithm Overview</u></strong></p>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
 The neural network will use unsupervised learning to perform vector
quantization, splitting the inputs into regions based on certain
features [3]. The feedforward architecture will be used because it
allows for the abstraction of high level features such as the ones we’re
 looking for [3]. The categorization/clustering process would be
repeated several times by different neural nets, each performing vector
quantization for a different feature set. The end result is that each
input sample (software repository) will be categorized in several ways
based on different features. An example overview of the process for
JavaScript libraries:</p>
<ol>
<li>“Documentation” neural net runs on repos, separating into three
regions: JsDoc, Standard Comments, or No Comments. Resulting category
for each repo is recorded.</li>
<li>“Paradigm” neural net runs on repos, separating into three regions:
Functional, Object-Oriented, or Procedural. Resulting category for each
repo is recorded.</li>
<li>(Repeat the idea of 1 and 2 for any other classifications desired)</li>
<li>Present the user with an interface for quickly scanning libraries.
Example UX: User sees table of all JavaScript libraries, filterable by
feature sets as categorized by the neural nets.</li>
</ol>
<p>The algorithm for the neural nets that actually perform the vector quantization would take roughly the following steps:</p>
<ol>
<li>Input layer: All source code from a given repository as one large
string, which is the concatenation of all source files with a given file
 extension.</li>
<li>First layer: Nodes get source input and generate output based on frequency of specific string occurrences.</li>
<li>Second layer: Nodes look at input from first layer and output the
probability of fitting a certain region. The probability is given by a
distance calculation (such as Euclidean distance) for the codebook
vector for each region [3]. There is only one node for each region.</li>
<li>Output layer: One node takes all of the inputs from the second layer
 and outputs a string (or if that’s not possible, an integer that maps
to a string) that denotes which region is most closely matched.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong><u>Citations</u></strong></p>
<p>[1] <a rel="noopener" href="https://gitlab.com/">https://gitlab.com/</a></p>
<p>[2] <a rel="noopener" href="https://github.com/">https://github.com/</a></p>
<p>[3] Mehrotra, Kishan, Chilukuri Mohan K., and Sanjay Ranka.<span>&nbsp;</span><em>Elements of Artificial Neural Networks</em>. Cambridge, Massachusetts: MIT, 1997. Print.</p></div>
																				</div>
